</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Slavery" title="Template:Slavery"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Slavery" title="Template talk:Slavery"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Slavery&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Slavery</b> and <b>enslavement</b> are both the state and the condition of being a <b>slave</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> who is someone forbidden to quit their service for an enslaver, and who is treated by the enslaver as their <a href="/wiki/Property" title="Property">property</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Slavery typically involves the enslaved person being made to perform some form of work while also having their location or residence dictated by the enslaver. Many historical cases of enslavement occurred when the enslaved broke the law, became indebted, or suffered a military defeat; other forms of slavery were instituted along demographic lines such as <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">race</a>. The duration of a person's enslavement might be for life, or for a fixed period of time, after which <a href="/wiki/Manumission" title="Manumission">freedom would be granted</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Although most forms of slavery are explicitly involuntary and involve the coercion of the enslaved, there also exists <a href="/wiki/Voluntary_slavery" title="Voluntary slavery">voluntary slavery</a>, entered into by the enslaved to pay a debt or obtain money. In the course of human history, slavery was a typical feature of <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilization</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slavery_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-Slavery-5">[5]</a></sup> legal in most societies, but it is now <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolition_of_slavery_timeline" title="Abolition of slavery timeline">outlawed</a> in most countries of the world, except as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penal_labor" title="Penal labor">punishment for a crime</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBales20044_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBales20044-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WhiteWhite2014_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-WhiteWhite2014-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <i>chattel slavery</i>, the enslaved person is legally rendered the <a href="/wiki/Personal_property" title="Personal property">personal property</a> (chattel) of the slave owner. In economics, the term <i>de facto slavery</i> describes the conditions of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unfree_labour" title="Unfree labour">unfree labour</a> and <a href="/wiki/Forced_labour" title="Forced labour">forced labour</a> that most slaves endure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newint_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-newint-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, approximately 40 million people, of whom 26 percent were children, were enslaved throughout the world despite it being illegal. In the modern world, more than 50 percent of enslaved people provide <a href="/wiki/Forced_labour" title="Forced labour">forced labour</a>, usually in the factories and sweatshops of the <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">private sector</a> of a country's economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> In industrialised countries, <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking" title="Human trafficking">human trafficking</a> is a modern variety of slavery; in non-industrialised countries, enslavement by <a href="/wiki/Debt_bondage" title="Debt bondage">debt bondage</a> is a common form of enslaving a person,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newint_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-newint-8">[8]</a></sup> such as captive <a href="/wiki/Domestic_worker" title="Domestic worker">domestic servants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Forced_marriage" title="Forced marriage">forced marriage</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_use_of_children" title="Military use of children">child soldiers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-modernslavery_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-modernslavery-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Terminology">Terminology<span class="anchor" id="Types"></span></span></h2>
<p>The word <span title="English-language text"><span lang="en">slave</span></span> arrived in modern English from <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a> <span title="Middle English (1100-1500)-language text"><i lang="enm">sclave</i></span>, from <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">Old French</a> <span title="Old French (842-ca. 1400)-language text"><i lang="fro">esclave</i></span>, from Late <a href="/wiki/Middle_High_German" title="Middle High German">Middle High German</a> <span title="Middle High German (ca. 1050-1500)-language text"><i lang="gmh">sklave</i></span>, from <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <span title="Medieval Latin-language text"><i lang="la">sclāvus</i></span>, from <a href="/wiki/Late_Latin" title="Late Latin">Late Latin</a> <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Sclāvus</i></span>, from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greek" title="Byzantine Greek">Byzantine Greek</a> <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">Σκλάβος</span></span> [<i>Sklábos</i>], <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">Έσκλαβήνος</span></span> [<i>Ésklabḗnos</i>].
</p><p>According to the widespread view, which has been known since the 18th century, Byzantine <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">Σκλάβινοι</span></span> [<i>Sklábinoi</i>], <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">Έσκλαβηνοί</span></span> [<i>Ésklabēnoí</i>], borrowed from Slavic gen self-name <span title="Church Slavonic-language text">*<i lang="cu">Slověninŭ</i></span> turned into <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">Σκλάβος</span></span>, <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">Έσκλαβήνος</span></span> (<a href="/wiki/Late_Latin" title="Late Latin">Late Latin</a> <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Sclāvus</i></span>) in the meaning 'prisoner of war Slave', 'slave' in 8th/9th century, because they often became captured and enslaved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis1992Chapter_1_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis1992Chapter_1-14">[14]</a></sup> However this version has been disputed since the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alternative contemporary hypothesis states that <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <span title="Medieval Latin-language text"><i lang="la">sclāvus</i></span> via <span title="Latin-language text">*<i lang="la">scylāvus</i></span> derives from Byzantine <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">σκυλάω</span></span> [<i>skūláō</i>, <i>skyláō</i>], <span title="Byzantine Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">σκυλεύω</span></span> [<i>skūleúō</i>, <i>skyleúō</i>] - "to strip the enemy (killed in a battle)", "to make booty / extract spoils of war".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> This version is criticized as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is a dispute among historians about whether terms such as "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unfree_labour" title="Unfree labour">unfree labourer</a>" or "<b>enslaved person</b>", rather than "slave", should be used when describing the victims of slavery. According to those proposing a change in terminology, <i>slave</i> perpetuates the crime of slavery in language by reducing its victims to a nonhuman noun instead of "carry[ing] them forward as people, not the property that they were". Other historians prefer <i>slave</i> because the term is familiar and shorter, or because it accurately reflects the inhumanity of slavery, with <i>person</i> implying a degree of autonomy that slavery does not allow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chattel_slavery">Chattel slavery</span></h3>
<p>As a social institution, chattel slavery classes slaves as <i>chattels</i> (<a href="/wiki/Personal_property" title="Personal property">personal property</a>) owned by the enslaver; like livestock, they can be bought and sold at will.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> While slavery in general was common throughout human history, the specific notion of chattel slavery reached its modern extreme in the Americas during European colonization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Beginning in the 18th century, a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolitionist" title="Abolitionist">abolitionist</a> movements saw slavery as a violation of the slaves' rights as people ("<a href="/wiki/All_men_are_created_equal" title="All men are created equal">all men are created equal</a>"), and sought to abolish it. Abolitionism encountered extreme resistance but was eventually successful; the last Western country to abolish slavery, Brazil, <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Brazil" title="Slavery in Brazil">did so in 1888</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The last <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Third-world" title="Third-world">third-world</a> country to abolish slavery, <a href="/wiki/Mauritania" title="Mauritania">Mauritania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Mauritania" title="Slavery in Mauritania">did not do so until 1981</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bonded_labour">Bonded labour</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Debt_bondage" title="Debt bondage">Debt bondage</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Money_marriage" title="Money marriage">Money marriage</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chukri_System" title="Chukri System">Chukri System</a></div>
<p>Indenture, otherwise known as bonded labour or debt bondage, is a form of unfree labour under which a person pledges himself or herself against a loan. The services required to repay the debt, and their duration, may be undefined. Debt bondage can be passed on from generation to generation, with children required to pay off their progenitors' debt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBales200415–18_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBales200415–18-27">[27]</a></sup> It is the most widespread form of slavery today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Debt bondage is most prevalent in South Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBales200415–18_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBales200415–18-27">[27]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Money_marriage" title="Money marriage">Money marriage</a> refers to a marriage where a girl, usually, is married off to a man to settle debts owed by her parents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chukri_System" title="Chukri System">Chukri System</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Debt_bondage_in_India" title="Debt bondage in India">debt bondage</a> system found in parts of <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> where a female can be coerced into <a href="/wiki/Prostitution" title="Prostitution">prostitution</a> in order to pay off debts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dependents">Dependents</span></h3>
<p>The word "slavery" has also been used to refer to a legal state of dependency to somebody else.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopedia1_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopedia1-31">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> For example, in <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persia</a>, the situations and lives of such slaves could be better than those of common citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Forced_labour">Forced labour</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slavery21.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1496" data-file-width="1944" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Slavery21.jpg/200px-Slavery21.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Slavery21.jpg/300px-Slavery21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Slavery21.jpg/400px-Slavery21.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slavery21.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Flogging a slave fastened to the ground</i>, illustration in an 1853 anti-slavery pamphlet</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="997" data-file-width="639" decoding="async" height="265" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg/170px-Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg/255px-Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg/340px-Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sale_of_negroes_1860.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A poster for a slave auction in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a>, U.S., 1860</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Woman-slave.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="608" data-file-width="492" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Woman-slave.jpg/170px-Woman-slave.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Woman-slave.jpg/255px-Woman-slave.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Woman-slave.jpg/340px-Woman-slave.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Woman-slave.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Portrait of an older woman in <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a> with her enslaved servant girl in the mid-19th century</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unfree_labour" title="Unfree labour">Unfree labour</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking" title="Human trafficking">Human trafficking</a></div>
<p>Forced labour, or unfree labour, is sometimes used to describe an individual who is forced to work against their own will, under threat of violence or other punishment, but the generic term "unfree labour" is also used to describe chattel slavery, as well as any other situation in which a person is obliged to work against their own will, and a person's ability to work productively is under the complete control of another person.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> This may also include institutions not commonly classified as slavery, such as <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">serfdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> and <a href="/wiki/Penal_labour" title="Penal labour">penal labour</a>. While some unfree labourers, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Serf" title="Serf">serfs</a>, have substantive, <i>de jure</i> legal or traditional rights, they also have no ability to terminate the arrangements under which they work and are frequently subject to forms of coercion, violence, and restrictions on their activities and movement outside their place of work.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Human trafficking primarily involves women and children forced into <a href="/wiki/Prostitution" title="Prostitution">prostitution</a> and is the fastest growing form of forced labour, with Thailand, Cambodia, India, Brazil and Mexico having been identified as leading hotspots of <a href="/wiki/Commercial_sexual_exploitation_of_children" title="Commercial sexual exploitation of children">commercial sexual exploitation of children</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voa_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-voa-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Child_soldiers_and_child_labor">Child soldiers and child labor</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Child_slavery" title="Child slavery">Child slavery</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Child_labour" title="Child labour">Child labour</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_use_of_children" title="Military use of children">Military use of children</a></div><p>In 2007, <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> estimated that 200,000 to 300,000 children served as soldiers in then-current conflicts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> More girls under 16 work as <a href="/wiki/Domestic_worker#Migrant_domestic_workers" title="Domestic worker">domestic workers</a> than any other category of child labour, often sent to cities by parents living in rural poverty<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> as with the Haitian <a href="/wiki/Restavek" title="Restavek">restaveks</a>.
</p><h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Forced_marriage">Forced marriage</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marriage_by_abduction" title="Marriage by abduction">Marriage by abduction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage" title="Child marriage">Child marriage</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Forced_marriage" title="Forced marriage">Forced marriages</a> or early marriages are often considered types of slavery.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Forced marriage continues to be practiced in parts of the world including some parts of Asia and Africa and in immigrant communities in the West.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sacred_prostitution" title="Sacred prostitution">Sacred prostitution</a> is where girls and women are pledged to priests or those of higher castes, such as the practice of <a href="/wiki/Devadasi" title="Devadasi">Devadasi</a> in South Asia or <a href="/wiki/Ritual_servitude" title="Ritual servitude">fetish slaves</a> in West Africa.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marriage_by_abduction" title="Marriage by abduction">Marriage by abduction</a> occurs in many places in the world today, with a 2003 study finding a national average of 69% of marriages in Ethiopia being through abduction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_uses_of_the_term">Other uses of the term</span></h3>
<p>The word <i>slavery</i> is often used as a pejorative to describe any activity in which one is coerced into performing. Some argue that <a href="/wiki/Conscription#Military_slavery" title="Conscription">military drafts</a> and other forms of coerced government labour constitute "state-operated slavery."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Some <a href="/wiki/Libertarianism" title="Libertarianism">libertarians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-capitalism" title="Anarcho-capitalism">anarcho-capitalists</a> view government taxation as a form of slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Slavery" has been used by some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antipsychiatry" title="Antipsychiatry">anti-psychiatry</a> proponents to define involuntary psychiatric patients, claiming there are no unbiased physical tests for mental illness and yet the psychiatric patient must follow the orders of the psychiatrist. They assert that instead of chains to control the slave, the psychiatrist uses drugs to control the mind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Drapetomania" title="Drapetomania">Drapetomania</a> was a pseudoscientific psychiatric diagnosis for a slave who desired freedom; "symptoms" included laziness and the tendency to flee captivity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some proponents of <a href="/wiki/Animal_rights" title="Animal rights">animal rights</a> have applied the term <i>slavery</i> to the condition of some or all human-owned animals, arguing that their status is comparable to that of human slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MSpiegel_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-MSpiegel-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>The labour market, as institutionalized under contemporary capitalist systems, has been criticized by mainstream <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialists</a> and by <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-syndicalism" title="Anarcho-syndicalism">anarcho-syndicalists</a>, who utilise the term <a href="/wiki/Wage_slavery" title="Wage slavery">wage slavery</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Pejorative" title="Pejorative">pejorative</a> or <a href="/wiki/Dysphemism" title="Dysphemism">dysphemism</a> for <a href="/wiki/Wage_labour" title="Wage labour">wage labour</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllerman1992_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllerman1992-51">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-merriam-webster.com_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-merriam-webster.com-52">[52]</a></sup> Socialists draw parallels between the trade of labour as a commodity and slavery. <a href="/wiki/Cicero" title="Cicero">Cicero</a> is also known to have suggested such parallels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Characteristics">Characteristics</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Private_versus_state-owned_slaves">Private versus state-owned slaves</span></h3>
<p>Slaves have been owned privately by individuals but have also been under state ownership. For example, the <a href="/wiki/Kisaeng" title="Kisaeng">kisaeng</a> were women from low castes in pre modern Korea, who were owned by the state under government officials known as <i>hojang</i> and were required to provide entertainment to the aristocracy; in the 2020s some are denoted <i><a href="/wiki/Kippumjo" title="Kippumjo">Kippumjo</a></i> (the pleasure brigades of North Korea — serving as the concubines of the rulers of the state).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> "Tribute labor" is compulsory labor for the state and has been used in various iterations such as <a href="/wiki/Corv%C3%A9e" title="Corvée">corvée</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mit%27a" title="Mit'a">mit'a</a> and <a href="/wiki/Repartimiento" title="Repartimiento">repartimiento</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Internment" title="Internment">internment camps</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Totalitarian" title="Totalitarian">totalitarian</a> regimes such as the Nazis and the Soviet Union placed increasing importance on the labor provided in those camps, leading to a growing tendency among historians to designate such systems as slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economics">Economics</span></h3>
<p>Economists have modeled the circumstances under which slavery (and variants such as <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">serfdom</a>) appear and disappear. One observation is that slavery becomes more desirable for <a href="/wiki/Land_tenure" title="Land tenure">landowners</a> where land is abundant but labour is scarce, such that rent is depressed and paid workers can demand high wages. If the opposite holds true, then it is more costly for landowners to guard the slaves than to employ paid workers who can demand only low wages because of the degree of competition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> Thus, first slavery and then serfdom gradually decreased in Europe as the population grew. They were reintroduced in the Americas and in Russia as large areas of land with few inhabitants became available.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Slavery is more common when the tasks are relatively simple and thus easy to supervise, such as large-scale <a href="/wiki/Monocropping" title="Monocropping">monocrops</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a>, in which output depended on <a href="/wiki/Economies_of_scale" title="Economies of scale">economies of scale</a>. This enables systems of labour, such as the <a href="/wiki/Gang_system" title="Gang system">gang system</a> in the United States, to become prominent on large plantations where field hands toiled with factory-like precision. Then, each work gang was based on an internal division of labour that assigned every member of the gang to a task and made each worker's performance dependent on the actions of the others. The enslaved chopped out the weeds that surrounded the cotton plants as well as excess sprouts. Plow gangs followed behind, stirring the soil near the plants and tossing it back around the plants. Thus, the gang system worked like an <a href="/wiki/Assembly_line" title="Assembly line">assembly line</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 18th century, critics have argued that slavery retards technological advancement because the focus is on increasing the number of slaves doing simple tasks rather than upgrading their efficiency. For example, it is sometimes argued that, because of this narrow focus, technology in Greece – and later in Rome – was not applied to ease physical labour or improve manufacturing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2240" data-file-width="2608" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg/220px-Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg/330px-Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg/440px-Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fathers_of_the_Redemption.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The work of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercedarians" title="Mercedarians">Mercedarians</a> was in ransoming Christian slaves held in North Africa (1637).</div></div></div>
<p>Scottish economist <a href="/wiki/Adam_Smith" title="Adam Smith">Adam Smith</a> stated that free labour was economically better than slave labour, and that it was nearly impossible to end slavery in a free, democratic, or republican form of government since many of its legislators or political figures were slave owners, and would not punish themselves. He further stated that slaves would be better able to gain their freedom under centralized government, or a central authority like a king or church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Similar arguments appeared later in the works of <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Comte" title="Auguste Comte">Auguste Comte</a>, especially given Smith's belief in the <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a>, or what Comte called the "separation of the spiritual and the temporal" during the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> and the end of slavery, and Smith's criticism of masters, past and present. As Smith stated in the <i><a href="/wiki/Lectures_on_Jurisprudence" title="Lectures on Jurisprudence">Lectures on Jurisprudence</a></i>, "The great power of the clergy thus concurring with that of the king set the slaves at liberty. But it was absolutely necessary both that the authority of the king and of the clergy should be great. Where ever any one of these was wanting, slavery still continues..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEForbes199874_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEForbes199874-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="482" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg/220px-The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg/330px-The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg/440px-The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_inspection_and_sale_of_a_slave.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sale and inspection of slaves</div></div></div>
<p>Even after slavery became a criminal offense, slave owners could get high returns. According to researcher <a href="/wiki/Siddharth_Kara" title="Siddharth Kara">Siddharth Kara</a>, the profits generated worldwide by all forms of slavery in 2007 were $91.2 billion. That was second only to drug trafficking, in terms of global criminal enterprises. At the time the weighted average global sales price of a slave was estimated to be approximately $340, with a high of $1,895 for the average trafficked sex slave, and a low of $40 to $50 for debt bondage slaves in part of Asia and Africa. The weighted average annual profits generated by a slave in 2007 was $3,175, with a low of an average $950 for bonded labour and $29,210 for a trafficked sex slave. Approximately 40% of slave profits each year were generated by trafficked sex slaves, representing slightly more than 4% of the world's 29 million slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dhaliwal_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dhaliwal-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Identification">Identification</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Negro_in_American_history_(microform)_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_(1914)_(14597416438).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2502" data-file-width="1702" decoding="async" height="323" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/The_Negro_in_American_history_%28microform%29_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_%281914%29_%2814597416438%29.jpg/220px-The_Negro_in_American_history_%28microform%29_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_%281914%29_%2814597416438%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/The_Negro_in_American_history_%28microform%29_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_%281914%29_%2814597416438%29.jpg/330px-The_Negro_in_American_history_%28microform%29_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_%281914%29_%2814597416438%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/The_Negro_in_American_history_%28microform%29_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_%281914%29_%2814597416438%29.jpg/440px-The_Negro_in_American_history_%28microform%29_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_%281914%29_%2814597416438%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Negro_in_American_history_(microform)_-_men_and_women_eminent_in_the_evolution_of_the_American_of_African_descent_(1914)_(14597416438).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Branding of a female slave</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="860" data-file-width="1146" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg/220px-A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg/330px-A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg/440px-A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_slave_market_in_Cairo-David_Roberts.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Barefooted slaves depicted in <a href="/wiki/David_Roberts_(painter)" title="David Roberts (painter)">David Roberts</a>' <i>Egypt and Nubia</i>, issued between 1845 and 1849</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slavery17.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="531" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Slavery17.jpg/220px-Slavery17.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Slavery17.jpg/330px-Slavery17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Slavery17.jpg/440px-Slavery17.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slavery17.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Slave branding, c. 1853</div></div></div>
<p>Throughout history, slaves were clothed in a distinctive fashion, particularly with respect to the frequent lack of footwear, as they were rather commonly forced to go <a href="/wiki/Barefoot" title="Barefoot">barefoot</a>. This was partly for economic reasons, but also served as a distinguishing feature, especially in South Africa and South America. For example, the <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a> slave code stated that "Slaves must go barefoot and must carry passes."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WCG_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-WCG-64">[64]</a></sup> It also puts slaves at a physical disadvantage because of the lack of protection against environmental conditions and in confrontations, thereby making it more difficult to escape or to rebel against their owners.
</p><p>This was the case in the majority of states. Most images from the respective historical period suggest that slaves were barefoot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-slavery_brazil_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-slavery_brazil-65">[65]</a></sup> Brother Riemer stated, "[the slaves] are, even in their most beautiful suit, obliged to go barefoot. Slaves were forbidden to wear shoes. This was a prime mark of distinction between the free and the bonded and no exceptions were permitted."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-living_conditions_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-living_conditions-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Bible, shoes have been considered badges of freedom since antiquity: "But the father said to his servants, Bring forth the best robe, and put [it] on him; and put a ring on his hand, and shoes on [his] feet" (<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bible_(King_James)/Luke#15:22" title="s:Bible (King James)/Luke">Luke 15:22</a>). This aspect can be viewed as an informal law in areas where slavery existed as any person sighted barefoot in public was assumed to be a slave.
</p><p>In certain societies this rule continues. The <a href="/wiki/Tuareg_people" title="Tuareg people">Tuareg</a> still unofficially practice slavery and force their slaves to remain barefoot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sklaven_barfuss_bei_Tuareg_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sklaven_barfuss_bei_Tuareg-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another widespread practice was <a href="/wiki/Human_branding" title="Human branding">branding</a>, either to explicitly mark slaves as property or as punishment.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_rights">Legal rights</span></h3>
<p>Depending upon the era and the country, slaves sometimes had a limited set of legal rights.  For example, in the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_New_York" title="Province of New York">Province of New York</a>, people who deliberately killed slaves were punishable under a 1686 statute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> And, as already mentioned, certain legal rights attached to the nobi in Korea, to enslaved people in various African societies, and to black female slaves in the <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_(New_France)" title="Louisiana (New France)">French colony of Louisiana</a>.  Giving slaves legal rights has sometimes been a matter of morality, but also sometimes a matter of self-interest.  For example, in <a href="/wiki/Classical_Athens" title="Classical Athens">ancient Athens</a>, protecting slaves from mistreatment simultaneously protected people who might be mistaken for slaves, and giving slaves limited property rights incentivized slaves to work harder to get more property.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In the southern United States prior to <a href="/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">the extirpation of slavery in 1865</a>, a proslavery legal treatise reported that slaves accused of crimes typically had a legal right to counsel, freedom from <a href="/wiki/Double_jeopardy" title="Double jeopardy">double jeopardy</a>, a right to trial by jury in graver cases, and the right to grand jury indictment, but they lacked many other rights such as white adults’ ability to control their own lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_slavery" title="History of slavery">History of slavery</a></div>
<p>Some scholars differentiate ancient forms of slavery from the largely race-based slavery. The first type of slavery, sometimes called "just title servitude", was inflicted on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_war" title="Prisoners of war">prisoners of war</a>, debtors, and other vulnerable people. Race-based slavery grew to immense proportions starting in the 14th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> It was argued even by some contemporary writers to be intrinsically immoral.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mines_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1738" data-file-width="2346" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Mines_1.jpg/220px-Mines_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Mines_1.jpg/330px-Mines_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Mines_1.jpg/440px-Mines_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mines_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Corinthian black-figure terra-cotta votive tablet of slaves working in a mine, dated to the late seventh century BC</div></div></div>
<p>Slavery predates written records and has existed in many cultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slavery_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-Slavery-5">[5]</a></sup>  Slavery is rare among <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a> populations because it requires economic surpluses and a substantial population density. Thus, although it has existed among unusually resource-rich hunter gatherers, such as the <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">American Indian</a> peoples of the <a href="/wiki/Salmon" title="Salmon">salmon</a>-rich rivers of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Northwest" title="Pacific Northwest">Pacific Northwest</a> coast, slavery became widespread only with the invention of agriculture during the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution">Neolithic Revolution</a> about 11,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ebhellie_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-ebhellie-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the earliest known records, slavery is treated as an established institution. The <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Hammurabi" title="Code of Hammurabi">Code of Hammurabi</a> (c. 1760 BC), for example, prescribed death for anyone who helped a slave escape or who sheltered a fugitive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsu._edu_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsu._edu-76">[76]</a></sup> The Bible <a href="/wiki/The_Bible_and_slavery" title="The Bible and slavery">mentions slavery</a> as an established institution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slavery_5-2"><a href="#cite_note-Slavery-5">[5]</a></sup> Slavery was practiced in almost every ancient civilization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slavery_5-3"><a href="#cite_note-Slavery-5">[5]</a></sup> Such institutions included debt bondage, punishment for crime, the enslavement of <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">prisoners of war</a>, <a href="/wiki/Child_abandonment" title="Child abandonment">child abandonment</a>, and the enslavement of slaves' offspring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_antiquity">Classical antiquity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_antiquity" title="Slavery in antiquity">Slavery in antiquity</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_ancient_Egypt" title="Slavery in ancient Egypt">Slavery in ancient Egypt</a></div>
<p>Slavery existed in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Pharaonic Egypt</a>, but studying it is complicated by terminology used by the <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptians</a> to refer to different classes of servitude over the course of history. Interpretation of the textual evidence of classes of slaves in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> has been difficult to differentiate by word usage alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> The three apparent types of enslavement in Ancient Egypt: chattel slavery, bonded labour, and forced labour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David_91_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-David_91-80">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Everett_10–11_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-Everett_10–11-81">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunn_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dunn-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia">Asia</span></h4>
<p>Slavery existed in ancient China as early as the <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Slavery was employed largely by governments as a means of maintaining a public labour force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Europe">Europe</span></h4>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_Greece_and_Rome">Ancient Greece and Rome</span></h5>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_ancient_Rome" title="Slavery in ancient Rome">Slavery in ancient Rome</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="910" data-file-width="1139" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png/250px-Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png/375px-Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png/500px-Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld_Bibel_in_Bildern_1860_038.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Ishmaelites" title="Ishmaelites">Ishmaelites</a> purchase <a href="/wiki/Joseph_(Genesis)" title="Joseph (Genesis)">Joseph</a></i>, by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Schnorr_von_Carolsfeld" title="Schnorr von Carolsfeld">Schnorr von Carolsfeld</a>, 1860</div></div></div>
<p>Records of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Ancient_Greece" title="Slavery in Ancient Greece">slavery in Ancient Greece</a> begin with <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">Mycenaean Greece</a>. <a href="/wiki/Classical_Athens" title="Classical Athens">Classical Athens</a> had the largest slave population, with as many as 80,000 in the 6th and 5th centuries BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>  As the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> expanded outward, entire populations were enslaved, across Europe and the Mediterranean. Slaves were used for labour, as well as for amusement (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Gladiator" title="Gladiator">gladiators</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sexual_slavery" title="Sexual slavery">sex slaves</a>). This oppression by an elite minority eventually led to <a href="/wiki/Slave_rebellion" title="Slave rebellion">slave revolts</a> (see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Servile_Wars" title="Roman Servile Wars">Roman Servile Wars</a>); the <a href="/wiki/Third_Servile_War" title="Third Servile War">Third Servile War</a> was led by <a href="/wiki/Spartacus" title="Spartacus">Spartacus</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6974" data-file-width="5533" decoding="async" height="315" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg/250px-Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg/375px-Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg/500px-Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_004.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Slave Market in Ancient Rome</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Jean-L%C3%A9on_G%C3%A9r%C3%B4me" title="Jean-Léon Gérôme">Jean-Léon Gérôme</a></div></div></div>
<p>By the late Republican era, slavery had become an economic pillar of Roman wealth, as well as Roman society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> It is estimated that 25% or more of the population of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Ancient Rome</a> was enslaved, although the actual percentage is debated by scholars and varied from region to region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harper2011_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harper2011-88">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Slaves represented 15–25% of <a href="/wiki/Roman_Italy" title="Roman Italy">Italy</a>'s population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scheidel_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scheidel-90">[90]</a></sup> mostly war captives,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scheidel_90-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scheidel-90">[90]</a></sup> especially from <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">Gaul</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joshel545560_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-Joshel545560-91">[91]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Epirus" title="Epirus">Epirus</a>. Estimates of the number of slaves in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> suggest that the majority were scattered throughout the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Province" title="Roman Province">provinces</a> outside of Italy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scheidel_90-2"><a href="#cite_note-Scheidel-90">[90]</a></sup> Generally, slaves in Italy were indigenous Italians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Foreigners (including both slaves and freedmen) born outside of Italy were estimated to have peaked at 5% of the total in the capital, where their number was largest. Those from outside of Europe were predominantly of Greek descent. Jewish slaves never fully assimilated into Roman society, remaining an identifiable minority. These slaves (especially the foreigners) had higher death rates and lower birth rates than natives and were sometimes subjected to mass expulsions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> The average recorded age at death for the slaves in Rome was seventeen and a half years (17.2 for males; 17.9 for females).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa_2">Africa</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Africa" title="Slavery in Africa">Slavery in Africa</a></div>
<p>Slavery was widespread in Africa, which pursued both internal and external slave trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senegambia_(geography)" title="Senegambia (geography)">Senegambia</a> region, between 1300 and 1900, close to one-third of the population was enslaved. In early Islamic states of the western <a href="/wiki/Sahel" title="Sahel">Sahel</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Empire" title="Ghana Empire">Ghana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mali_Empire" title="Mali Empire">Mali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bamana_Empire" title="Bamana Empire">Segou</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Songhai_Empire" title="Songhai Empire">Songhai</a>, about a third of the population were enslaved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="910" data-file-width="829" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg/200px-Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg/300px-Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg/400px-Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Slaves_Zadib_Yemen_13th_century_BNF_Paris.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>13th-century slave market in <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Saharan_slave_trade" title="Trans-Saharan slave trade">trans-Saharan slave trade</a>, slaves from <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a> were transported across the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara desert</a> to <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a> to be sold to <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle eastern</a> civilizations. The <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean_slave_trade" title="Indian Ocean slave trade">Indian Ocean slave trade</a>, sometimes known as the east African slave trade, was multi-directional. Africans were sent as slaves to the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> islands (including <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a>), to the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, and later to the Americas. These traders captured <a href="/wiki/Bantu_peoples" title="Bantu peoples">Bantu peoples</a> (<a href="/wiki/Zanj" title="Zanj">Zanj</a>) from the interior in present-day <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mozambique" title="Mozambique">Mozambique</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a> and brought them to the coast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Och_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-Och-98">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ogot_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ogot-99">[99]</a></sup> There, the slaves gradually assimilated in rural areas, particularly on <a href="/wiki/Unguja" title="Unguja">Unguja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pemba_Island" title="Pemba Island">Pemba</a> islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lodhi_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lodhi-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Americas">Americas</span></h4>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aztec_slavery" title="Aztec slavery">Slavery in Mexico</a> can be traced back to the <a href="/wiki/Aztecs" title="Aztecs">Aztecs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> Other <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Amerindians</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Inca_Empire" title="Inca Empire">Inca</a> of the Andes, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tup%C3%AD_people" title="Tupí people">Tupinambá</a> of Brazil, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muscogee_people" title="Muscogee people">Creek</a> of Georgia, and the <a href="/wiki/Comanche" title="Comanche">Comanche</a> of Texas, also practiced slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slavery_5-4"><a href="#cite_note-Slavery-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Canada" title="Slavery in Canada">Slavery in Canada</a> was practiced by <a href="/wiki/First_Nations_in_Canada" title="First Nations in Canada">First Nations</a> and by <a href="/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="European colonization of the Americas">European settlers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LawsonLawson2019_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-LawsonLawson2019-102">[102]</a></sup> Slave-owning people of what became Canada were, for example, the fishing societies, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yurok_tribe" title="Yurok tribe">Yurok</a>, that lived along the Pacific coast from Alaska to California,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> on what is sometimes described as the Pacific or Northern Northwest Coast. Some of the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Pacific_Northwest_Coast" title="Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast">indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Haida_people" title="Haida people">Haida</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tlingit_people" title="Tlingit people">Tlingit</a>, were traditionally known as fierce warriors and slave-traders, raiding as far as California. Slavery was hereditary, the slaves being <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_war" title="Prisoners of war">prisoners of war</a> and their descendants were slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> Some nations in British Columbia continued to segregate and ostracize the descendants of slaves as late as the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AboriginalSlavery_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-AboriginalSlavery-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia_2">Asia</span></h4>
<p>Slavery also existed in <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_India" title="Slavery in India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Japan" title="Slavery in Japan">Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Vietnam" title="Slavery in Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="China">China</span></h5>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_China" title="Slavery in China">Slavery in China</a></div>
<p>Many <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a> were enslaved in the process of the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_China" title="Mongol conquest of China">Mongol invasion</a> of <a href="/wiki/China_proper" title="China proper">China proper</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997146–147_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997146–147-106">[106]</a></sup> According to Japanese historians Sugiyama Masaaki (杉山正明) and Funada Yoshiyuki (舩田善之), Mongolian slaves were owned by <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Korea">Korea</span></h5>
<p><a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Korea" title="Slavery in Korea">Slavery in Korea</a> existed since before the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Three Kingdoms of Korea">Three Kingdoms of Korea</a> period, in the first century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997392–393_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997392–393-109">[109]</a></sup> Slavery has been described as "very important in medieval Korea, probably more important than in any other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Asian" title="East Asian">East Asian</a> country, but by the 16th century, population growth was making [it] unnecessary".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Klein2014_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-Klein2014-110">[110]</a></sup> Slavery went into decline around the 10th century but came back in the late <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a> period when Korea also experienced multiple <a href="/wiki/Slave_rebellion" title="Slave rebellion">slave rebellions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997392–393_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997392–393-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Joseon" title="Joseon">Joseon</a> period of Korea, members of the slave class were known as <i>nobi</i>. The nobi were socially indistinct from freemen (i.e., the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chungin" title="Chungin">middle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sangmin" title="Sangmin">common</a> classes) other than the ruling <a href="/wiki/Yangban" title="Yangban">yangban</a> class, and some possessed property rights, and legal and civil rights. Hence, some scholars argue that it is inappropriate to call them "slaves",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> while some scholars describe them as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Serfs" title="Serfs">serfs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2004153–157_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2004153–157-112">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> The nobi population could fluctuate up to about one-third of the total, but on average the nobi made up about 10% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997392–393_109-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodriguez1997392–393-109">[109]</a></sup> In 1801, the majority of government nobi were emancipated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> and by 1858, the nobi population stood at about 1.5 percent of the Korean population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2004162–163_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2004162–163-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Europe_2">Europe</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Barbary_slave_trade" title="Barbary slave trade">Barbary slave trade</a> and <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_Byzantine_Empire" title="Slavery in the Byzantine Empire">Slavery in the Byzantine Empire</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1310" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg/310px-Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg/465px-Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg/620px-Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gniezno_Boleslaus_II.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Adalbert_of_Prague" title="Adalbert of Prague">Adalbert of Prague</a> pleads with <a href="/wiki/Boleslaus_II,_Duke_of_Bohemia" title="Boleslaus II, Duke of Bohemia">Boleslaus II, Duke of Bohemia</a> for the release of slaves</div></div></div>
<p>Large-scale trading in slaves was mainly confined to the South and East of <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">early medieval</a> Europe: the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> were the destinations, while <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">pagan</a> <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> (along with the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tartary" title="Tartary">Tartary</a>) were important sources. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viking" title="Viking">Viking</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_people" title="Arab people">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radhanite" title="Radhanite">Radhanite</a> <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jewish</a> merchants were all involved in the slave trade during the Early Middle Ages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> The trade in European slaves reached a peak in the 10th century following the <a href="/wiki/Zanj_Rebellion" title="Zanj Rebellion">Zanj Rebellion</a> which dampened the use of African slaves in the Arab world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_medieval_Europe" title="Slavery in medieval Europe">Slavery in early medieval Europe</a> was so common that the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> repeatedly prohibited it, or at least the export of Christian slaves to non-Christian lands, as for example at the <a href="/wiki/Koblenz#Middle_Ages" title="Koblenz">Council of Koblenz</a> (922), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_London_(1102)" title="Council of London (1102)">Council of London (1102)</a> (which aimed mainly at the sale of English slaves to Ireland)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thomas_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thomas-121">[121]</a></sup> and the Council of Armagh (1171). <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">Serfdom</a>, on the contrary, was widely accepted. In 1452, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Nicholas_V" title="Pope Nicholas V">Pope Nicholas V</a> issued the <a href="/wiki/Papal_bull" title="Papal bull">papal bull</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Dum_Diversas" title="Dum Diversas">Dum Diversas</a></i>, granting the kings of Spain and Portugal the right to reduce any "Saracens (Muslims), pagans and any other unbelievers" to perpetual slavery, legitimizing the slave trade as a result of war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> The approval of slavery under these conditions was reaffirmed and extended in his <i><a href="/wiki/Romanus_Pontifex" title="Romanus Pontifex">Romanus Pontifex</a></i> bull of 1455.
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Britain">Britain</span></h5>
<p>In Britain, slavery continued to be practiced following the fall of Rome, and sections of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hywel_the_Good" title="Hywel the Good">Hywel the Good</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Welsh_law" title="Welsh law">laws</a> dealt with slaves in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medieval_Wales" title="Medieval Wales">medieval Wales</a>. The trade particularly picked up after the Viking invasions, with major markets at <a href="/wiki/Chester" title="Chester">Chester</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> supplied by Danish, Mercian, and Welsh raiding of one another's borderlands. At the time of the <i><a href="/wiki/Domesday_Book" title="Domesday Book">Domesday Book</a></i>, nearly 10% of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_England" title="Norman England">English</a> population were slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/William_the_Conqueror" title="William the Conqueror">William the Conqueror</a> introduced a law preventing the sale of slaves overseas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> According to historian <a href="/wiki/John_Gillingham" title="John Gillingham">John Gillingham</a>, by 1200 slavery in the British Isles was non-existent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gillingham8-9_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gillingham8-9-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>Slavery had never been authorized by statute within England and Wales, and in 1772, in the case <a href="/wiki/Somerset_v_Stewart" title="Somerset v Stewart">Somerset v Stewart</a>, Lord Mansfield declared that it was also unsupported within England by the common law. The slave trade was abolished by the <a href="/wiki/Slave_Trade_Act_1807" title="Slave Trade Act 1807">Slave Trade Act 1807</a>, although slavery remained legal in possessions outside Europe until the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Slavery_Abolition_Act_1833" title="Slavery Abolition Act 1833">Slavery Abolition Act 1833</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Slavery_Act,_1843" title="Indian Slavery Act, 1843">Indian Slavery Act, 1843</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, when England began to have colonies in the Americas, and particularly from the 1640s, African slaves began to make their appearance in England and remained a presence until the eighteenth century. In Scotland, slaves continued to be sold as chattels until late in the eighteenth century (on the second May, 1722, an advertisement appeared in the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Evening_Courant" title="Edinburgh Evening Courant">Edinburgh Evening Courant</a></i>, announcing that a stolen slave had been found, who would be sold to pay expenses, unless claimed within two weeks).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>For nearly two hundred years in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_coal_mining" title="History of coal mining">history of coal mining</a> in Scotland, miners were bonded to their "maisters" by a 1606 Act "Anent Coalyers and Salters". The <a href="/wiki/Colliers_and_Salters_(Scotland)_Act_1775" title="Colliers and Salters (Scotland) Act 1775">Colliers and Salters (Scotland) Act 1775</a> stated that "many colliers and salters are in a state of slavery and bondage" and announced emancipation; those starting work after 1 July 1775 would not become slaves, while those already in a state of slavery could, after 7 or 10 years depending on their age, apply for a decree of the Sheriff's Court granting their freedom. Few could afford this, until a further law in 1799 established their freedom and made this slavery and bondage illegal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_129-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-129">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Empire">Ottoman Empire</span></h5>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="621" data-file-width="825" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg/290px-Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg/435px-Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg/580px-Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Captain_walter_croker_horror_stricken_at_algiers_1815.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A British captain witnessing the miseries of slaves in <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Algeria" title="Ottoman Algeria">Ottoman Algeria</a>, 1815</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Ottoman_Wars" title="Byzantine–Ottoman Wars">Byzantine-Ottoman wars</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_wars_in_Europe" title="Ottoman wars in Europe">Ottoman wars in Europe</a> brought large numbers of slaves into the Islamic world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> To staff its bureaucracy, the Ottoman Empire established a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Janissaries" title="Janissaries">janissary system</a> which seized hundreds of thousands of Christian boys through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dev%C5%9Firme" title="Devşirme">devşirme</a> system. They were well cared for but were legally slaves owned by the government and were not allowed to marry. They were never bought or sold. The empire gave them significant administrative and military roles. The system began about 1365; there were 135,000 janissaries in 1826, when the system ended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lepanto_(1571)" title="Battle of Lepanto (1571)">Battle of Lepanto</a>, 12,000 Christian galley slaves were recaptured and freed from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_fleet" title="Ottoman fleet">Ottoman fleet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> Eastern Europe suffered a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongol_and_Tatar_states_in_Europe" title="Mongol and Tatar states in Europe">Tatar invasions</a>, the goal of which was to loot and capture slaves for selling them to Ottomans as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jasyr" title="Jasyr">jasyr</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-slave_trade_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-slave_trade-134">[134]</a></sup> Seventy-five Crimean Tatar raids were recorded into <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Poland–Lithuania</a> between 1474 and 1569.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
